I'm Bob Kaplan,
professor emeritus
at the Harvard Business School.

If we're going to make progress
in reducing greenhouse gas

emissions, we have to look not
just at individual corporations
but their supply chains.

The existing standard for this
doesn't measure their content
accurately.

It allows these
organizations to measure

them using industry
averages, which

means that a company
or an institution that

does an exceptional
job in sourcing

low-carbon products and
services can't get the benefit.

Fundamental insight in
creating the e-liability method

really is drawn upon inventory
accounting and cost accounting.

The inventory accounting
idea is that information

from a supplier can be
transmitted up to its customer.

In the case of traditional
inventory accounting,
it's the price.

But for environmental
accounting,

it will be the carbon content
in the products and services
they purchase to them.

The cost accounting idea is
for the company, the supplier,
that's doing this calculation.

It has to take the carbon
content of the products

and services it purchased as
inputs, add it to the carbon

emissions it produces in
its production process,

and assigns it to its
outputs which it can then
transfer up to its customers.

We have to know
where we are today

and then be able to measure
the reduction as organizations

change the design
of their products

and also the sourcing and
procurement of their inputs.

Karthik Ramanna, my
colleague and co-conspirator

here for the last 12
months, is working

with several high-polluting
organizations in cement,

in tire manufacturing, and
steel to test and apply

the e-liability
method in practice.

The companies that have been
using it are very enthusiastic.

They feel it's kind
of the solution they'd
been looking for.

So right now, the
existing standard

is lax enough that it's
treated as a reporting

requirement, a
disclosure requirement,

but not as a management
tool that we can actively

use in designing our products
and in choosing the suppliers
of our inputs for our products.

We've wasted 20 years
of opportunities

in decarbonizing supply chains,
which we can now address.
